oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Douglas C-124 Globemaster II
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of a Douglas CF-124 Globemaster II flying in the air. It is missing the radar "thimble" on the nose, therefore it is most likely the early C-124A model. Image is an official U.S. Air Force Photograph taken at the Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio, Texas.

The Douglas C-124 Globemaster II was the primary heavy-lift transport for the United States Air Force Military Air Transport Service (MATS). MATS was activated on June 1, 1948 to be responsible for all U.S. military transport requirements. MATS was a consolidation of the United States Navy's Naval Air Transport Service (NATS) and the United States Air Force's Air Transport Command (ATS) into a single joint command, under the control of the newly constructed United States Air Force. Air Force pilots flew Navy MATS planes, just as naval aviators could be found piloting Air Force MATS transport aircrafts. MATS was inactivated on January 8, 1966.
